body: Operation name relate to endpoint metrics. Please consider carefully. We don't bring too many unnecessary endpoint id

> Operation name relate to endpoint metrics. Please consider carefully. We don't bring too many unnecessary endpoint id

I got it. Usually, we don't subscribe too many topics by many different `group.id` in one agent. Otherwise, `group.id` is usuful for analysis. I think we could consider doing it.

> I got it. Usually, we don't subscribe too many topics by many different group.id in one agent. Otherwise, group.id is usuful for analysis. I think we could consider doing it.

For Kafka, I agree. `queue/groupid` is your proposal?

> I'm not familiar with Cassandra at all, but according to the API, you just intercept the method `SessionManager#executeAsync` and nothing more, which returns a `ResultSetFuture`, if I didn't misunderstand this, the request to Cassandra server did not complete here until the method `ResultSetFuture#getUninterruptibly`(or `ResultSetFuture#cancel`) is called, and, if the `getUninterruptibly ` throws (say `TimeoutException`), the request actually failed but your plugin would record it as success, doesn't it? And if the client calls `ResultSetFuture#cancel`, the status should be recorded (perhaps as `TAG`, WDYT @wu-sheng ). @stone-wlg Please correct me if I'm wrong

i don't get your point, do you mean when exception occurred or user cancel what should happened? if yes, what is the right way to do in skywalking ?

> but finally other execute will call executeAsync(Statement var1), so i only intercept this method.

@stone-wlg It is absolutely OK to intercept just the `executeAsync`, what I meant is that you should take care of the **final** state of the request, while `executeAsync` doesn't indicate that the request is completed, in case that it is `canceled` or timed out, and this should be recorded in the span somehow

> > but finally other execute will call executeAsync(Statement var1), so i only intercept this method.

@stone-wlg For async, in order to make sure exit span duration accuration. Besides intercepting callback and creating local span there, you should take a look at AsyncSpan APIs, finish the exit span in async mode.

@kezhenxu94 I have made some commits that I think solve the broken trace problem. If rpc happens, then two segments generated, which show as two rows. When you set two service codes at agent.config, at trace page and topology, you should see them linked.

You should update to rocketbot latest commit id. What do you do? I am seeing conflicts.

You should fork and clone the repo. Do submodule update. Then, go into skywalking-ui folder, pull the latest of UI master branch. At this point, you will notice, maim repo changlog will show submodule commitid changed, the new one matching the UI master branch commitid.
All these could be learn from any doc or blog talking about git submodule.

I have taken a look, you are using `#Main`, which could finish before agent registered. So basically, this is not SkyWalking use case. SkyWalking is application performance monitoring, application means a server, not a simple main func.
@hanahmily I am moving this to 6.5 again, as it is not updated recently.
/run ci
@wu-sheng  Ok, I will submit the new PR
@wu-sheng  pushed agian，big thanks for your help 🍺

Oh I see, `com.networknt.exception.ExceptionHandler#handleRequest` does execute across threads so then another segment is indeed expected. Thank you!

As for why there are so many spans: based on discussions with @stevehu and other Light4J developers, we would like to see detailed information on the `LightHttpHandler`s that are involved during the life of a HTTP request in a Light4J project, in addition to the tracing from the Undertow plugin. Do you foresee any problems with the number of spans being created? My screenshots are from using an example Light4J project so I think this will be the typical amount.
/run ci

SkyWalking is not just a tracing project, it is an APM, so the data you generated related to metrics and topology. And SkyWalking is designed and used in 100% trace sampling and only reasonable resource cost. So first of all, too many spans are performance concerns. Also, APM is focusing on business code performance, rather than framework. We are assuming framework has no big performance issue, but the duration of span still includes the framework cost, in this case including undertow and light4j.

Then, do you generate entry span for light4j? If yes, it exista with undertow entry span, rather than override it, which cause service request counter incorrectly. +2 for every request. When you create an entry span inside the undertow entry span, the override should happen automatically. Also this override should be able to make the icon/type of topology node showing as a light4j service.


If you really think light4j should add many spans, such as you have cases useful for end user, consider to add a plugin config, and share with us why. 

The ideas is mostly about, we are monitoring performance, rather than telling developer what light4j do and how it forward request, even in tech level, we could, but don't fit production requirement.

Do I make myself clear?
@artemsre Document is improved, I will merge the PR after CI passed.

The light-4j is based on the undertow and we have created so many middleware handlers to form handler chains for each individual endpoint. As these middleware handlers can be enabled or disabled through config files, our users would like to know how many middleware handlers were passed through before reaching the business handler. It would be great for the APM to capture the information if possible. If you think SkyWalking is not designed for this, do you happen to know what other options do we have? If we don't do need to capture all middleware handler spans, do you think we should just use the Undertow agent? Thanks a lot for your help.
Replaced by #3390
FYI @dmsolr Please review.

> If you think SkyWalking is not designed for this, do you happen to know what other options do we have? 

We could, just don't recommend always set this in default. Consider providing an option in Config.

> If we don't do need to capture all middleware handler spans, do you think we should just use the Undertow agent? Thanks a lot for your help.

An example is, Spring is also doing handler thing, right? We set SpringMVC `@Controller` as entry span, so when a user uses Tomcat + SpringMVC, the user sees `@Controller` as the only entry span. That is what I mean override. Light4j entry span overrides undertow span.
Undertow agent is not the concern, it should disappear if you set entry span for light4j. 

Anyway, there are only suggestions, the only requirement is, don't make `light4j` and `undertwo` entry spans both exist.
